title: What is Date of Separation?
question: I was married in Jan 2007. Things did not work out well. We got separated on April-2007. However I was trying to work out marriage. My wife stoped communicating with me. She showed no interest in resuming marriage/cohabitation. I stopped my further efforts to reconcile on Dec-2007.
question_tags: Divorce,Divorce and joint accounts,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Alimony,Divorce and bankruptcy,Child custody,Bankruptcy,Joint accounts during bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and alimony,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Family law
answers:
The date of separation is the date one of you communicates to the other that you want out of the marriage. This date is extremely important in that it is a cut-off date for marital assets and debts AND, in short term marriages (less than 10 years), a cut-off for spousal support (generally, half the duration of the marriage). For that reason, people often spend a lot of time and money in attorney's fees battling over the date of separation. It does often happen that one spouse says s/he wants out but then goes into counseling with the other spouse to try and save the marriage. Maybe they stay together for economic reasons, or for the kids. Things muddies the water for what exactly is the date of the separation - hence, mini-trials over this one issue. People often feel the other spouse is not putting in the same interest and/or effort in counseling. What the courts look at is how you held yourselves out to the public - did you still attend functions as husband and wife, did you put all of your income into a joint account, and much more.

Regardless of the date you choose, you may, in fact qualify for a summary dissolution, as my colleagues have mentioned. The statutory limit is 5 years of marriage (not 6 months). But there are also a number of other requirements that must ALL be met in order to proceed. These include, but are not limited to, no children, no interest in Real Property other than a lease that must be for less than one year, no request for spousal support. So if either of you owns a house, whether separate or community, you will not qualify. If you do qualify, there is generally only one court filing fee, the process is purely administrative (paper work), and most attorneys charge around $400-$500 to do it.

A prior answer to this question is INCORRECT as to the effect of this difference in date of separation on the availability of a California Summary Dissolution. As per the California state courts website, a Summary Dissolution is available to dissolve any marriage of less than five YEARS, which meets the other requirements..

The advantage of using the earlier date is that it allows you to get a summary divorce, i.e., a quickie divorce provided there are no property or child custody issues. If the marraige lasted more than 6 months you cannot use this procedure.

April 2007 is the date to use. It is better for you and is definitely the date she intended to separate. Efforts at reconciliation that are unilateral do not change the separation date.
